instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging problem
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in with no power, not charging. <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> was visibly burned so I replaced it along with <CAPACITOR>C7091</CAPACITOR> which was dead short and appears to have been at least one of the problems. Now when I plug in the charger I get 16.5 volts on the <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> side of <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>, but only about 2.5 volts on the <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_CONN_R</SIGNAL> side. I have replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> but no change. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> goes to about .7 volts when plugged in and then starts to drop while the probes are connected.

<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> was blemished and measuring 15 ohms. I also replaced that and measured all other resistors in the area which tested good.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> .700V and dropping when probes are attached diode mode shows .124V

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.5V

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.41V

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> 2.14V

<SIGNAL>DCIN_ISOL_GATE</SIGNAL> 6.8V

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 16.5V


Logic board is very clean and shows no signs of moisture/corrosion. Any suggestions are appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging problem
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

You must get correct <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> first.
Check if <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is still good (47 ohm) and check diode mode to ground at <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>.
If low, remove <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR>/2 (one by one) and check again; <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is the last suspect.
Don't fotget to check <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging problem
threads.message: Thanks for the welcome and for assisting me with this issue. <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> was in fact the problem and now I have a functional charging system! For some reason though, the fan does not work. I tested it using a power supply and it is definitely capable of spinning. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is present at the connector as well as 3.3V on pin 4, <SIGNAL>FAN_RT_TECH</SIGNAL>. That lead me to believe that there was something possibly wrong with <SIGNAL>FAN_RT_PWM</SIGNAL>. Diode mode there shows .510V. Following that to <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> it seems that <RESISTOR>R6060</RESISTOR> was a bit low. About 23k instead of 47k so I replaced it and when that did not change anything, I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR>. Still no fan. Since <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> gets data from the SMC is that the next place to look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> charging problem
threads.message:
Do NOT touch fan circuitry.
It doesn't spin until CPU gets really hot on this model!
